dt: {bc}to put or bring back into existence or use
{bc}to bring back to or put back into a former or original state {bc}{sx|renew||}
{bc}to put again in possession of something

pt: {sc}renew{/sc} {sc}restore{/sc} {sc}refresh{/sc} {sc}renovate{/sc} {sc}rejuvenate{/sc} mean to make like new. {sc}renew{/sc} implies a restoration of what had become faded or disintegrated so that it seems like new.

pt.t: efforts to {it}renew{/it} the splendor of the old castle

pt: {sc}restore{/sc} implies a return to an original state after depletion or loss.
{sc}refresh{/sc} implies the supplying of something necessary to restore lost strength, animation, or power.
{sc}renovate{/sc} suggests a renewing by cleansing, repairing, or rebuilding.
{sc}rejuvenate{/sc} suggests the restoration of youthful vigor, powers, or appearance.

pt.t: the change in jobs {it}rejuvenated{/it} her spirits

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}restorer{/it}, from Latin {it}restaurare{/it} to renew, rebuild, alteration of {it}instaurare{/it} to renew
shortdef: to put or bring back into existence or use
to bring back to or put back into a former or original state : renew
